coredata.dc:title: Investigation of ozonation kinetics and transformation products of sucralose
coredata.prism:copyright: Â© 2017 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
coredata.dc:creator: Hu, Ruikang
Zhang, Lifeng
Hu, Jiangyong
coredata.dc:description: Sucralose is one of widely used artificial sweeteners, which has been ubiquitously detected in various water sources, such as wastewater and randomly in reservoir water. It is also reported to be persistent to various water treatment techniques. Although there are some studies on removal of sucralose by advanced oxidation process, limited information, in terms of reaction kinetics, transformation products and degradation pathway etc., was reported in its ozonation process. In this study, the reaction kinetics, removal efficiency, influence of pH, humic acid and carbonate on sucralose degradation by ozone, have been studied systematically. The results demonstrated that ozonation of sucralose was initiated by the formation of OH radical. Sucralose could be completely removed with excess O3 at neutral and basic conditions in ultrapure water. The rate of degradation decreased significantly in acidic condition and in the presence of carbonate and OH radical scavenger (e.g. tert-butanol). The acidity was the key factor affecting the degradation of sucralose. The rate constant was about 500 times higher at pH7 than that at pH4. Transformation products study indicated that the ozonation of sucralose were more complex than that in photolysis reaction. Although ozonation of sucralose was initiated by OH radical, both OH radical and O3 might be involved in the formation of transformation products and total organic carbon (TOC) removal. Various transformation products, such as aldehydes, carboxylic acids and probable chloride containing products, were identified and characterized in details. An ozonation degradation pathway of sucralose was proposed as well.

head.ce:title: Investigation of ozonation kinetics and transformation products of sucralose

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: Sucralose is one of widely used artificial sweeteners, which has been ubiquitously detected in various water sources, such as wastewater and randomly in reservoir water. It is also reported to be persistent to various water treatment techniques. Although there are some studies on removal of sucralose by advanced oxidation process, limited information, in terms of reaction kinetics, transformation products and degradation pathway etc., was reported in its ozonation process. In this study, the reaction kinetics, removal efficiency, influence of pH, humic acid and carbonate on sucralose degradation by ozone, have been studied systematically. The results demonstrated that ozonation of sucralose was initiated by the formation of OH radical. Sucralose could be completely removed with excess O3 at neutral and basic conditions in ultrapure water. The rate of degradation decreased significantly in acidic condition and in the presence of carbonate and OH radical scavenger (e.g. tert-butanol). The acidity was the key factor affecting the degradation of sucralose. The rate constant was about 500 times higher at pH7 than that at pH4. Transformation products study indicated that the ozonation of sucralose were more complex than that in photolysis reaction. Although ozonation of sucralose was initiated by OH radical, both OH radical and O3 might be involved in the formation of transformation products and total organic carbon (TOC) removal. Various transformation products, such as aldehydes, carboxylic acids and probable chloride containing products, were identified and characterized in details. An ozonation degradation pathway of sucralose was proposed as well.

ce:section.ce:para: Artificial sweeteners are used as food additives as they provide a sweet taste to food but have few calories, thus they are also known as non-nutritive sweeteners (NNS) (FDA, 2006). Seven artificial sweeteners, such as sucralose (SUC), saccharin, aspartame, acesulfame potassium, neotame, stevia, and Luo Han Guo extract etc., are approved by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) (Pepino et al., 2013).

Sucralose is about 600 times sweeter by weight than sucrose, which has been widely used in over 80 countries and in >4000 different products (Sharma et al., 2012; Torres et al., 2011). There are about 1500ton and 400ton sucralose consumed every year in USA and Europe, respectively (Sharma et al., 2014).

Sucralose is very stable with a half-life of several years (Scheurer et al., 2009). It is also stable in human body, there is >98% consumed SUC unchanged in human excretion (Lange et al., 2012). Various studies showed that SUC was persistent to environment and water treatment processes (Pasquini et al., 2013). For example, there was only 20% of SUC converted to CO2 in 14days with the rate of 1.43ng SUC/kg per day in a 0.1Î¼g SUC/kg of soil (Labare and Alexander, 1994). There was no significant degradation of SUC in aerobic or anaerobic biological reactors after 42â62days; and there was only 7.8% of SUC degraded with UV light irradiation up to 24h. At free chlorine concentration (0.1mM), which is normally applied in the wastewater treatment plants (WWTPs), there was only 1.5% of SUC degraded in 96h, while 79% of SUC could be degraded when the free chlorine concentration was increased to 100mM (Torres et al., 2011). Furthermore, as the octanol-water partition coefficient (logÂ·Kow) of SUC is 0.3, SUC will be present in aqueous phase and is less bioaccumulated (Tollefsen et al., 2012; Hoque et al., 2014). Therefore, SUC may accumulate in natural waters over time due to its increased consumption, and persistence to water treatment (Lubick, 2008). In US, sucralose was detected in source water of 15 out of 19 drinking water treatment plant (DWTPs) at the concentration level of 47ngÂ·Lâ1â2900ngÂ·Lâ1, finished water of 13 out of 17 DWTPs at the concentration level of 49ngÂ·Lâ1â2400ngÂ·Lâ1 and distribution system water of 8 out of 12 DWTPs at the concentration level of 48ngÂ·Lâ1â2400ngÂ·Lâ1 in US (Mawhinney et al., 2011). SUC was detected in all samples of septic tank effluent and all groundwater samples in the concentration range of 6â98Î¼gÂ·Lâ1 and 0.7â77Î¼gÂ·Lâ1, respectively, in Canada (Robertson et al., 2016). In Germany, 2.7Î¼gÂ·Lâ1 SUC was detected in wastewater effluent (Oppenheimer et al., 2011), and SUC were detected in the range of 2.2â9.1Î¼gÂ·Lâ1 in the influent and effluent of WWTP of Zurich (Switzerland) (Buerge et al., 2009). Thus, SUC was recommended as an ideal chemical marker of domestic wastewater in groundwater (Oppenheimer et al., 2011; Buerge et al., 2009; De Sousa et al., 2014). SUC was used as one of chemical markers in the human fecal pollution source tracking toolbox (Tran et al., 2015).

Although SUC is generally recognized as safe for use, the concerns of long-term impacts of sucralose to the human health and environment have attracted many research interests due to its stability in environment, persistence to treatment processes, potential accumulation in aquatic environment and widely applications. It was reported that the SUC could interfere with plant photosynthesis and change organisms' feeding behaviors (Lubick, 2008). Based on Ecological Structure Activity Relationship Model (ECOSAR) developed by USEPA, when the concentration was higher than 1123mgÂ·Lâ1 (chronic lowest no effect concentration of green algae), SUC may cause toxicity to aquatic organisms (Tollefsen et al., 2012; USEPA, 2010). By oral gavage of splenda (containing 1.1% of sucralose) from 100â1000mgÂ·kgâ1 to male Sprague-Dawley rats for 12-wk., the study by Abou-Donia et al. also showed a decrease in gastrointestinal microflora and an increase in expression of cytochrome P450 and P-glycoprotein (Abou-Donia et al., 2008). However, no adverse effects were observed in green algae, Lemna gibba, with 1800mgÂ·Lâ1 of SUC for 96h (Smyth, 1986), and Lemna gibba with concentration of 114mgÂ·Lâ1 for 7days (Lillicrap, 2011). Compared with SUC concentrations detected in the various environments as discussed above, these concentrations are too high to be environmentally relevant. There was no observed toxicity in Nitocra spinipes for 96h exposure at concentrations of 10mgÂ·Lâ1 (Wiklund et al., 2012). The toxic effect of Cd2+ and Cu2+ to S. obliquus decreased with the presence of 1mg Lâ1 of SUC, while impacts of SUC to the growth of S. obliquus was not significant (Hu et al., 2016a).

In the last few years, there were only few studies have been conducted on the SUC ozonation in water. Hollender et al. (2009) reported that only about 31% of SUC could be eliminated with 0.6gO3 gâ1 DOC. Scheurer et al. (2010) reported that SUC was persistent during ozonation, with removal of 8â15% in waterworks and <20% after 30min in the batch test. Torres et al. (2011) reported that estimate the rate constant of k =4.5Ã10â3 Â±1Ã10â3 Mâ1 sâ1 of SUC ozonation in the presence of both O3 and OH as oxidants at pH7.2. Study of Soh et al. (2011) showed that the initial first order reaction rate of SUC ozonation was 0.00427sâ1. In these studies, only Soh et al. (2011) reported that 6% of 0.39mgÂ·Lâ1 sucralose could be removed by 4.8mgÂ·Lâ1 ozone after 1h. The degradation of sucralose by ozone was completely hindered in the addition of 0.5mM t-butanol (TBA) as a radical quench, suggested a radical mediated oxidation. However, the rate constant was determined only at around neutral condition and only the effect of TBA on the SUC ozonation was studied. Other parameters such as humic acid (HA), carbonate, and pH were no studied in details. Therefore, there is need to conducted more details kinetics studies on the SUC ozonation.

Further studies on the toxicity and environment impacts of SUC and its transformation products (TPs) showed that the inhibition of the luminescence of Vibrio fischeri which was exposed to photocatalytic irradiated sucralose sample (15mgÂ·Lâ1) increased in the first 1h and decreased after 2h (Calza et al., 2013). At pH3, only <1% of sucralose was hydrolyzed to 1, 6- dichloro-1,6-dideoxy-d-fructose (1,6-DCF) and 4-chloro-4-deoxy- D-galactose (4-CG) in one year at 25Â°C (Grice and Goldsmith, 2000; Labare and Alexander, 1994). Thermal degradation products polychlorinated aromatic hydrocarbons and chloropropanols were observed when temperature was higher than 120Â°C (De Oliveira et al., 2015; Rahn and Yaylayan, 2010). Polychlorinated dibenzo-p-dioxins and dibenzofurans (PCDD/PCDF) were detected in smoke and residues generated from heated SUC, and the presence of CuO enhanced the formation of PCDD/PCDF in comparison with Al2O3 and Fe2O3 (Dong et al., 2013). For SUC samples treated with UV/H2O2, two products with m/z of 361, 379 and 381 were detected (Keen and Linden, 2013). Similarly, various [Na]+ adduct of SUC photocatalytic degradation products, e.g. m/z C12H19O9Cl3Na, C12H19O10Cl3Na and C12H22O10Na etc. were also reported by Calza et al. (2013). However, there is no ozonation products of SUC reported. The effects of these TPs, formed during water treatment process, on the environment and human health are still not very clear.

The objective of this study is to investigate the kinetics of SUC ozonation, the effect of pH and water matrix on the removal of SUC by O3, ozonation TPs and the possible ozonation pathways via the application of modern analytical techniques, so as to provide qualitative and quantitative information on ozonation of sucralose in water.

SUC, acetonitrile (ACN), methanol (MeOH), formic acid (FA), acetic acid (AA), oxalic acid (OXA) and sodium thiosulfate, sodium carbonate and humid acid were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich Co. Deionized (DI) water was obtained by passing tap water through a Milli-Q integral 5 system (Millipore, Singapore) with a resistivity >18.2MÂ·Î©Â·cmâ1 and an on-line TOC <5Î¼gÂ·Lâ1. Stock solution of SUC, FA, AA and OXA were prepared in DI water at 1000mgÂ·Lâ1 and further diluted to the calibration level in DI water for quantitation. Humic acid stock solution was prepared by dissolving 2g of humic acid in 1L of DI water at pH10 adjusted by addition of 0.1molLâ1 NaOH solution and filtered through a 0.45Î¼m filter, and stored in an amber bottle at 4Â°C. 2mM of carbonate (total (CO3 2 â +HCO3 â)) stock solution was prepared by dissolving 0.216g Na2CO3 in 1L DI water at pH10 adjusted by addition of 0.1molÂ·Lâ1 NaOH solution.

A model Lab2b ozone generator (Triogen Ltd., Scotland), was fed with pure O2 to generate O3. Stock ozone solution was prepared by continuously bubbling ozone gas produced from ozone generator, into iced DI water for about 1h, and the concentration of ozone solution was measured by UV spectrometer (Shimadzu Model 2450 UVâVis Spectrophotometers) at wavelength of 258nm and calculated based on Beer-Lambert Law. The aqueous ozone solution was transferred into the individual test bottles with glass pipettes or by plastic dispensers. Batch ozonation experiments were conducted in a beaker at room temperature (20Â°C) at different pH and concentrations. Ozonation experiments were conducted by continuously bubbling ozone gas into 10mgÂ·Lâ1 SUC solution or by adding calculated volume of stock ozone solution into 10mgÂ·Lâ1 or 1mgÂ·Lâ1 SUC solution. Replicated experiments were performed for all experiments. The ozonated SUC samples were collected at reaction time of 5s, 10s, 20s, 40s and 60s, and quenched by addition of 20Î¼L 10% Na2S2O3 solution and analysed with different methods.

Ultra performance liquid chromatography coupled with time of flight mass spectrometry (UPLC-QTOF) (Waters I-class UPLC coupled with XevoÂ® G2-S QTOF, USA) system was used in the identification and quantification of sucralose and its TPs of ozonation, via the measurement of retention time and accurate mass. Xevo G2-S QTOF parameters were set under negative electrospray resolution mode, capillary 1.5kV (3.0kV at positive mode), cone 27kV, desolvation gas 900LÂ·hâ1, cone flow 50mLÂ·minâ1, source temperature 120Â°C and source offset 80. LockSpray setup, detector setup, and resolution optimization have to be performed with 1ngÎ¼Lâ1 leucine encephalin to ensure the source is under normal operating conditions and optimized resolution can be achieved. The system has to be calibrated with 0.5mM sodium formation solution before sample analysis. MS method was set at MSe centriod mode, with thae scan range at m/z 50â600 at a collision energy of 4V, while MS/MS data were collected with the collision energy ramping from 12V to 35V. MSe acquisition mode can collect both exact-mass precursor and product ion (MS and MS/MS) information from a single injection in a data-independent manner. The centroid data format is used for small-molecule identification. The raw spectra from the detector are summed for the duration of the scan time, and then the data are converted to âstickâ form and preserving mass and intensity information.

Sucralose and its TPs were separated by Kinetex C-18 (2.6Î¼m, 100Ã2.1mm) column and Kinetex PFP column (2.6Î¼m, 150Ã4.6mm, Phenomenex Inc., USA) at flow rate of 0.5mLÂ·minâ1, with 0.1% FA in DI water and acetonitrile as mobile phase. The details of UPLC program were showed in Table S1.

In this study, the unique ions in the ozonated samples were identified by various techniques through Waters MassLynx software (MarkerLynx), such as principle component analysis (PCA), chromatogram subtraction, samples comparison, elemental composition, and isotopic patterns of fragment ions etc. The strategies to identify primary TPs of SUC were similar to that we applied in the identification of ozonation products of salicylic acid (Hu, et al., 2016b). As there was no chemical standard, the proposed TPs and their structure could not be confirmed and quantified in this study.

Aldehydes and ketones were monitored by solid phase microextraction (SPME) coupled with gas chromatography mass spectrometry (GCâMS) (Agilent Technologies, United States). To increase the sensitivity of detection, these compounds were converted to carbonylâpentafluorobenzyl hydroxylamineoxime derivatized by adding 200Î¼L of 0.3% O-(2,3,4,5,6-pentafluorophenyl) methylhydroxylamine hydrochloride (PFBHA) into 5mL sample, and analysed by SPME-GCâMS. The detail of derivatization process and SPME-GCâMS method was showed in Text S1, Table S2 and Table S3.

Carboxylic acids (e.g. formic acid, acetic acid and oxalic acid) and chloride were measured by ion chromatography (Dionex integrated IC system, model ICS-5000+ high-pressure IC system, USA) with conductivity detector. NaOH eluent was generated by eluent generation Cartridge. The sample was separated by IonPac AS19-HC-4mm anion-exchange column (4Ã250mm) with 0.9mM NaOH solution at a flow rate of 1mLÂ·minâ1. The detail of ion chromatography instrumentation was showed in Text S2.

Sucralose can be detected by UPLC-QTOF at both positive and negative modes, the spectra of SUC at positive and negative modes were showed as Fig. 1 below. Various fragment ions and adduct ions were observed in the spectra (Murray et al., 2013). There were three ions at m/z 395.0066 [SUC-H]â, 430.9828 [SUC+Cl]â and 441.0125 [SUC+HCOO]â formed at negative mode (Fig. 1A). While there was only one adduct ion at m/z 419.0036 [SUC+Na]+ formed at positive mode (Fig. 1B). Ions with m/z 395.0075 at negative mode and m/z 419.0056 at positive mode were used as quantitation ion, respectively in this study. In order to detect more TPs of SUC, ozonated SUC samples were run at both negative and positive modes.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Rate of degradation and kinetic study on the ozonation of sucralose
ce:section.ce:para: It is well known that pH value and sample matrix could affect the O3 and OH radical concentration in the sample, as well as ozonation reaction kinetic and mechanism. In this section, the influence of pH on the SUC ozonation in DI water and the effects of carbonate and humic acid on the SUC ozonation were discussed in details.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Influence of pH on degradation of sucralose
ce:section.ce:para: To investigate the reaction kinetic of ozone and sucralose, ozone gas was continuously purged into 10mgÂ·Lâ1 of SUC water solution at pH4, pH7 and pH10 with O2 as feed gas at a flow rate of 1LÂ·minâ1.

As showed in the Fig. 2 below, the reaction of O3 with SUC well followed pseudo-first rate of reaction in the excess of O3 at different pH conditions. At pH4, there was no significant change of SUC concentration within the first10min. The rate of constants was 5.9minâ1, 7.5minâ1 and 1.2Ã10â2 minâ1 for pH7, pH10 and pH4, respectively (Table S3). The rate constants slightly increased when pH increased from 7 to 10, which implied that the effect of pH on the SUC degradation was not significant in the pH range from 7 to 10. At pH7 and pH10, SUC demonstrated much higher rate constants than that at acidic condition during ozonation process. Almost 100% of SUC could be removed in 1min by continuously bubbling O3. The results are expected as high pH could promote the formation of OH radical, resulted in the increase of O3 reactivity towards SUC. It suggested that OH radical reaction dominated SUC ozonation reaction instead of O3 molecule.

In contrast, the rate constants of SUC were almost 500 to 600 times slower at acidic condition than that at neutral and alkaline conditions. The rate constant of SUC ozonation increased with the increase of pH. As OHâ is an initiator of O3 decay, the formation of OH radical could be accelerated at high pH (Gottschalk et al., 2000), resulting in high OH radical concentration at high pH. Therefore, the major reactive specie is OH radical at high pH. These results implied that the reaction between ozone and sucralose was probably initiated by the OH radical. To confirm it, the reaction was extended to 30min at pH4 and tert-butanol (TBA) was added into the solution as OH radical scavenger at pH10 (pH10/TBA). The rate constants of SUC ozonation at pH4 and pH10/TBA were showed in Fig. 2 and Table S4. Since TBA is a radical scavenger, the presence of TBA would suppress the radical chain reaction and inhibit the formation of OH radical, resulted in low OH concentration and low rate constant. The results indicated that both pH and TBA would have significantly impact on the reaction of SUC with ozone. This further demonstrated that ozonation of SUC was mainly through OH radical reaction. Although the presence of TBA could inhibit the formation of OH radical, which resulted in the decrease of rate constant, the rate constant SUC ozonation at pH10/TBA was around 20 times higher than that at pH4. SUC was almost completely degraded in 30min at pH10/TBA, while there was only about 30% was removed at pH4 with continuously bubbling ozone gas for 30min. However, the effect of acidic condition is higher than the addition of TBA as scavenger.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Influence water matrix on the ozonation of sucralose
ce:section.ce:para: As various components, such as natural organic matters and carbonate etc., are present in the natural water, the effect of water matrix, such as humic acid (HA) and carbonate (CO3 2â)/bicarbonate (HCO3 â) on the SUC ozonation are of great interest, the experiments were conducted by continuously bubbling of O3 gas into 10mgÂ·Lâ1 SUC samples in DI water, DI water with 2mgÂ·Lâ1 of HA and DI with 2mM carbonate (total (CO3 2 â +HCO3 â)) addition at pH7, denoted as pH7, pH7/HA and pH7/CO3 respectively.

The results indicated that pH was the key factor affecting SUC degradation by ozone and water treatment at neutral condition might be effective in the removal of SUC in water. However, the presence of carbonate and natural organic matters (e.g. HA), especially carbonate, would dramatically inhibit SUC ozonation. This result could well explain the low rate of degradation of SUC during ozonation in the water treatment plant in the previous report (Scheurer et al., 2010).

ce:section.ce:section-title: Removal efficiency of sucralose by ozonation
ce:section.ce:para: As discussed above, pH is the key factor which affects the ozonation of SUC, due to the reaction of SUC with ozone solution is an indirect oxidation process through the formation of OH radical. pH not only affected the rate constant, but also the removal efficiency. SUC could be completely removed in the DI water within minutes with continuous bubbling of ozone at neutral and basic conditions (Fig. 3 ). However, there was only about 30% of SUC removed after continuously bubbling of ozone at pH4. In the presence of water matrix (HA or carbonate), the removal efficiency was reduced, due to the competition or inhibition of OH radical formation. For example, about 2min reaction time was needed to remove >99% of SUC in the presence of 2mgÂ·Lâ1 HA, while only about 80% of SUC could be removed in the presence of 2mM carbonate. However, the removal efficiency was dramatically reduced in the presence of TBA (Fig. 2).

Further study demonstrated that there was about 85% of SUC removed in DI water, while the rate of degradation was decreased to 35%~40% and 20%~30% in the presence of HA and carbonate, respectively at the initial concentrations of 1mgÂ·Lâ1 of SUC and 1mgÂ·Lâ1 of O3 in 10min at pH7.

The experiments also indicated that the rate constants of SUC degradation and TOC reduction increased with the increase of O3 dosage. However, there was only 20%~30% of TOC could be removed when almost 90% of SUC degraded by ozonation (Fig. 3). Meanwhile, the extent of TOC reduction showed that the ultimate TOC removal rate was higher at pH7 than that at pH10, up to 30% of SUC can be completely mineralized, while only about 15% of SUC was mineralized at pH10. This suggested that the presence of O3 molecule might enhance the extent of mineralization of SUC and its TPs. It can be explained that the excess ozone fed into the system might enhance further degradation of intermediates.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Characterization of ozonation transformation products of sucralose
ce:section.ce:para: Based on the experiments results discussed above, ozonation of SUC was mainly initiated by the formation of OH radical chain reactions. However, the presence of O3 molecule in the samples might also be involved in further oxidation of TPs of SUC. Thus, the reaction of SUC ozonation is more complex than the direct reaction of SUC with OH radical generated by photolysis. TPs proposed in this study were also different from that proposed by Keen and Linden (2013) and Calza et al. (2013) (See Table 1 ).

ce:section.ce:section-title: Chloride elimination in the ozonation of sucralose
ce:section.ce:para: Chloride was detected in the ozonated sucralose sample by IC as showed in Fig. 4 . It was found that chloride concentration was increased with the increased ozone dose at both pH7 and pH10, while the concentration of SUC was decreased. There was no significant difference of chloride concentration in the degradation of SUC at pH7 and pH10. It was also observed that the concentration of Clâ was increased with the increase of ozone dose and tended to be completely eliminated. This suggested that the final TPs of SUC might be compounds without chloride in the excess ozone condition, such as aldehydes, and carboxylic acids etc. However, there was no sucrose and glucose detected in the samples. In another study with the limited O3 dose, (e.g. O3/SUC=1:1 (mgÂ·Lâ1/mgÂ·Lâ1)), chloride was not completely eliminated, implying that chlorine containing TPs might be generated. The details of dechlorinated TPs will be discussed in Section 3.4.

There were four aldehydes, formaldehyde, acetaldehyde glyoxal, and methyl glyoxal detected in the ozonated SUC samples. The concentrations of these aldehydes were increased with the increase of ozone dose and time of reaction, and decreased after the CO3/C SUC >15 (molar ratio) (Fig. S1). The maximum concentrations of HCHO and glyoxal were at 62Î¼gÂ·Lâ1 and 41Î¼gÂ·Lâ1 at pH7, while the maximum concentrations of HCHO and glyoxal were at 57Î¼gÂ·Lâ1 and 9.7Î¼gÂ·Lâ1 at pH10.

It was observed that the concentrations of acetaldehyde, glyoxal and methyl glyoxal were higher at pH7 than that at pH10, possibly because that O3 molecule might be involved in the SUC degradation and formation of small aldehydes molecules. The reaction of SUC with OH via H-abstractions mainly occurred at the Î±-C of OH group (Von Sonntag, 2006). Since OHâ could promote O3 decay and form OH radical, the concentration of O3 is higher at pH7 than that at pH10. At pH7, O3 might directly reacted with ozonation TPs of SUC. Thus, more aldehydes were tending to be formed at low pH than that at high pH, which implied that direct ozone reactions might be mainly responsible for the formation of small organic compounds. It was complied with the previous studies (HoignÃ©, 1982; Schechter and Singer, 1995; Hammes et al., 2006).

As the concentration of aldehydes generated from ozonation of SUC were only at Î¼gÂ·Lâ1 level, it might not cause human health issue. Instead, the presence of low concentration of aldehydes in the water might result in taste and odour issue in drinking water.

Three carboxylic acids, formic acid, acetic acid and oxalic acid were detected in the ozonated SUC samples by IC. As these acids are relative stable in the ozone solution, they tend to be accumulated in the samples (HoignÃ© and Bader, 1983; Buxton et al., 1988; Hu et al., 2016b). The concentrations of acids were increased with the increase of ozone dose and reaction time. The major acid detected in this study was OXA, with the maximum concentration of OXA of 2.6mgÂ·Lâ1 and 2.4mgÂ·Lâ1 at pH7 and pH10 respectively, which accounted for about 20% of initial SUC (Fig. S2). The maximum concentration of FA and AA were in the range of 0.1â0.2mgÂ·Lâ1.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Application of QTOF analysis and identification of ozonation transformation products and degradation pathway
ce:section.ce:para: As discussed in the Section 2.2, various fragment ions and adducts (Clâ, HCOOâ and Na+) might be formed in the LC-MS when formic acid was used as additive in the mobile phase. To increase detection capability, the ozonated SUC samples and its PFBHA derivatization samples were analysed at both positive and negative modes with on C-18 and PFP column with UPLC-QTOF system (See supplementary material Table S1 and Table S2 for the details of UPLC and derivatization methods).

Although the ozonation of SUC was initiated and dominated by OH radical reaction, the formation of TPs with ozone solution is more complicated, since both O3 molecule and OH radical are presented in the system. The ozonation intermediates might react with either O3 molecule or OH, thus, ozonation TPs of SUC were different from those solely reacting with OH.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Identification and structure elucidation of ozonation transformation products of sucralose
ce:section.ce:para: Sucralose is relatively stable compared with unsaturated organic compounds. The locations of chlorine on the cyclic moiety rings, methyl group, and hydroxyl group on the methyl group are the potential reactive sites with active species OH or O3 in the ozonation process (Keen and Linden, 2013). As the chlorine on the six-member ring has poor ability to withdraw electrons from cycloaliphatic moiety rather than chloromethyl group and the steric hindrance effect of OH attacking chlorines in chloromethyl groups (Keen and Linden, 2013), the substitution of chlorine by OH on the six-member ring might be easier than other two chlorine atoms. The detected fragment ions (TPs of SUC moieties) were showed in Table 1.

Based on the response intensities of fragment/adduct ions, the major ions detected by UPLC-QTOF at negative mode were m/z 391.0199, 407.0149 and 403.0189. The influence of ozone dose on the degradation of SUC and formation of TPs was showed in Fig. 5 . TPs, with relative response area to initial SUC <1%, were not showed in Fig. 5. As all these TPs (in Table 1) have similar structure and there was no pure chemical standard, the response might be used to estimate their concentrations relative to initial SUC.

The results showed that the concentrations of primary ozonation products of SUC increased with the O3 dose increase. However, their concentrations decreased in the excess of O3. This implied that these primary products might be completely removed in the excess of O3 and generated further oxidation products, i.e. carbonyl compounds, and carboxylic acids.

By the application of elemental composition tool and isotopic pattern comparison, the detected ions m/z 391.0199 at negative mode and adduct ion m/z 415.0173 at positive mode are attributed to the formula C12H18O10Cl2 and C12H18O10Cl2Na, which was one of major fragment ion identified TP in this study. The proposed structure is compound D in Scheme 1 , which might be one of biodegradation product proposed by Labare and Alexander (1994). The formation of this compound might be through both oxidation of âCH2OH to âCOOH, and Cl substitution by OH. As showed in Fig. S2, there were three peaks with m/z 391.0199, which were corresponding to 3 potential locations of chlorine substitution (Fig. S3). The chlorine atom on six atoms ring was the preferential site to be substituted by OH radical than that on the methyl group. The peak was higher than other two peaks. It was noticed that the total response area of all three was about 8% of the response area of SUC (Fig. 5).

The fragment ion m/z 407.0159 was another major fragment ion detected in the ozonated SUC sample with proposed structure as compounds E/F/G (C12H18O11Cl2) in Scheme 1. As showed in the Fig. S4, which might be a monohydroxylation/oxidation product of SUC and m/z 391.0199 (C12H18O10Cl2) was one of its fragment ions. The maximum response area detected in the ozonated sample was about 2.5% of SUC (Fig. 5).

Three fragment ions, m/z 381, 379 and 361 were reported as dominant products of SUC via UV/H2O2-based AOP which was proposed by Keen and Linden (2013). However, all of them were not detected in this study. At positive mode, m/z 381 was detected, however, the accurate mass (m/z 381.0114, attributed to the adduct ion C12H16O8Cl2Na+ ([M+Na]+) was different from C12H22O9Cl2 (m/z 381.0719, Cl on the six member ring substituted by OH, and 2H addition) (Fig. S5). As there was 0.06Da difference in m/z, a different structure was proposed in this study (compound A in Scheme 1), which might be an unsaturated aldehyde of SUC (biodegradation product) proposed by Labare and Alexander ((Labare and Alexander, 1994; Lappin-Scott et al., 1987). The presence of m/z 357.0147 ([M-H]â), 403.0189 ([M+HCOO]â) and 392.9811 ([M+Cl]â) at negative mode might further confirm the formula of C12H16O8Cl2 (Spectra showed in Fig. S6). The response area of compound A was about 1% of response area of initial SUC. Further study on the PFHBA derived samples, detected ion with m/z 552.0243 was detected with the empirical formula of C19H17NO8F5Cl2, suggested the presence of carbonyl group in compound C12H16O8Cl2, thus proposed structure of compound A in Scheme 5â1.

Compound H, the major TP of SUC at pH4, which accounted for about 10% of initial response area of SUC after 30min of reaction, was only detected at pH4. Possibly, it was because of relative lower reactivity of O3 than OH radical. This might also imply that the formation of âCHO (aldehyde) group was via the reaction of oxidation by O3 molecule, which was a different degradation pathway from that at basic condition.

Fragment ion m/z 221.0189 (C6H11O5ClNa) detected at positive mode was attributed to molecular formula of C6H11O5Cl (compound K). It might be the proposed hydrolysis products (4-CG) of SUC in acidic condition by Grice and Goldsmith (2000). Compounds K was also detected in the PFBHA derivatization samples of SUC, at m/z 392.0318 (theoretical formula C13H12NO5F5Cl), which possibly was 4-CG, a structure broken products of SUC. Spectra of compounds B, C, K and J were showed in Fig. S6. Although, there was <1% SUC hydrolysis in acidic condition in previous study, our study showed that 4-CG could be a major product of SUC during ozonation. The maximum response area was about 24% of initial SUC. (* The structure of 4-CG is very different from SUC, the response area to SUC might not represent its concentration well).

Although that SUC was stable in aqueous environment in the acidic condition, (Molinary and Quinlan, 2012), the results in this study showed that the hydrolysis was much faster than that in the presence of O3. However there was no detected 1,6-DCF, another hydrolysis products reported by Grice and Goldsmith (2000), possible due to the detected methods used in this study were not appropriate, or other products might be generated.

As showed in the Table 1, ozonation of SUC was through the substitution of Cl with OH radical and possible ring cleavage. Eleven molecular structures were proposed based on the detected fragment ions or the adduct ions on the UPLC-QTOF at negative and positive modes, and the previous reports (Calza et al., 2013; Labare and Alexander, 1994; Lappin-Scott et al., 1987; Keen and Linden, 2013; Soh et al., 2011).

To summarize the results discussed above, the concentration of TPs increased with ozone dose increase and decreased after O3/SUC were higher than 2:1 in molar ratio. The maximum concentrations of TPs were achieved at O3/SUC around 2:1 for compounds A and D. The maximum concentration of TPs were achieved at O3/SUC around 10:1 for compounds C, E/F/G and J. TPs were almost completely degraded in the excess O3. However, these TPs could be accumulated in the samples with limited O3 dose (e.g. 1:1 in molar ratio).

Besides these compounds, compounds with carbonyl groups (e.g. molecular formula C5H8O5 and C4H6O5 etc.) were detected from the PFBHA derivatization samples (Table S4). In addition, it is expected that compounds with carboxyl groups, which might not be detected in this study, might be formed during ozonation process.

According to the results discussed above, ozonation products of sucralose could be classified as four types: primary ozonation products (e.g. compounds with part of sucrose, or glucose moieties structure), carbonyl compounds, carboxylic acids and mineralization products (CO2) etc. The final ozonation TPs varied with the experimental conditions, such as pH, ozone dose and time of reaction etc. Based on the results discussed above and probable ozonation mechanism, 11 probable molecular structures and a proposed degradation pathway of sucralose via ozonation was showed in Scheme 1. As sucralose molecule is a highly hydroxylated molecule, the potential reactive sites are CCl, CH2 OH, chloromethyl groups (CH2 Cl on the five atoms ring), and âOH on the ring structure etc. The following mechanisms might be involved in the degradation of SUC, oxidation of OH on the methyl group, HCl elimination, Cl & H substitution, and cleavage of glycosidic bond. Formation of small molecular weight carbonyl compound might involve the cleavage of glycosidic bond, ring cleavage etc. Although the reaction was initiated by OH radical reaction, both OH and O3 might react with primary ozonation products of SUC and lead to formation of small molecular weight carbonyl compounds and low molecular weight carboxylic acids, e.g. OXA, FA, and AA etc. (Hu et al., 2016b).

In the SUC molecule, âOH group on the methyl group is relatively active than others on the ring structure, which could be substituted by OH, forming carbonyl group by the elimination of H2O molecule. Cl on six atom ring is relatively active than that on the chloromethyl groups, which could be substituted by OH. Based on Fig. 5, the major ozonation products of sucralose was compounds D and E/F/G. Function group âCH2 OH on the six atoms ring of SUC could be oxidized to âCHO via OH substitution. Meanwhile as CCl bond on the six atoms ring is the weakest CCl bond, substitution of Cl would generate compound D. Further substitution of H atom of compound D could occur at different positions, resulting in three isomer compounds E, F and G.

Formation of compound A might be initiated by the oxidation of OH group on the methyl group of SUC, resulting in the formation of aldehyde group, resulting in compound H. Meanwhile, an HCl molecule could be eliminated to form CC bond in compound A. H atom on the compound A could be substituted by OH, forming compound B. Furthermore, H atom on the five atoms ring of Compound B could be hydroxylated by OH and formed compound C. Formation of compound J might be initiated by the oxidation of OH group on the methyl group of SUC without HCl elimination, and hydroxylated H atom on the five atoms ring of SUC. In case of highly excess of O3, the directly cleavage of glycosidic bond of sucralose molecule and its primary ozonation products might occur and generate compound K, as well carbonyl compounds and carboxylic acids.

In this study the ozonation kinetics, removal efficiency and influence of pH and water matrix on the SUC degradation were investigated. The results indicated that SUC could be effectively removed by ozone at pH7 and pH10 with excess ozone in DI water. The rate of SUC degradation was significantly reduced, in acidic condition, and in the presence of OH radical scavenger, humic acid and carbonate. There was only about 30% SUC could be degraded at pH4 in 30min, while it was completely removed in 1min at pH10 with continuously bubbling of O3 in the samples. Although degradation of SUC was mainly through OH reaction, both O3 and OH might react with intermediates and form different TPs than that in photolysis reaction was reported. Formaldehyde, glyoxal and oxalic acid were the main aldehydes and carboxylic acids detected in the ozonated SUC samples. Aldehydes might be further oxidized in the excess of O3, while OXA was accumulated in the study. Various chloride containing TPs were identified and characterized in this study. Three detected ions with m/z 391.0199, 407.0151 and 221.0189, might attributed to unsaturated aldehyde of SUC, sucralose uronic acid and 4-CG were detected in the ozonated SUC samples. SUC degradation pathway was proposed based on the identified transformation products. The information demonstrated in this study will help better understand factors affecting the degradation of SUC by ozonation and the formation of transformation products.

ce:acknowledgment.ce:para: I would like to take this opportunity to thank the help of my colleagues in the testing of TOC and carboxylic acids in PUB lab and the help of lab staff in NUS WST lab in the ozonation experiment setup.

ce:section.ce:para: Supplementary data to this article can be found online at http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.scitotenv.2017.06.033.
